Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of painted rock art (round head period?) on rock face showing two human figures, one quadruped animal three unidentified shapes, infilled. The human figures are both upright, painted in dark brown pigment and facing left, each with the left arm raised and bent at the elbow. The figure on the left is holding both arms to the left and is superimposed at the waist by a large antelope pointing up and right, with body in light brown and underbelly highlighted in faded white pigment. Above are the legs of another human figure. Between both human figures is a small human figure facing left and waving arms as if stumbling. Karkur Talh, Egypt. Scanned
Curator's comments: This site is in the west bank of a blocked wadi which one flowed into the wadi with the waterfall site [2013.2034.1-4]. A crude shelter with a rough solid-rock floor about 6m wide and 25m deep; just over 1m high. Karkur Tahl is the largest wadi (dry seasonal riverbed valley) in the sandstone eastern section of Jebel Uweinat, a granite and sandstone massif on the border of Egypt, Libya and Sudan. Karkur Talh is around 25 km long and lies mostly in Sudan, but partly within Egypt’s borders. There is an abundance of both painted and engraved rock art in shelters in the smaller side wadis. The engravings were first revealed to academia by Ahmed Hassanein in 1923 and a few photographs published in his report on the journey in National Geographic in 1924. A more comprehensive publication of rock art sites in Karkur Talh was made by Prince Kemal el Dine with Abbe Breuil in 1925 following his discovery of a painted cave in Karkur Talh. Further exploration and publications were made by numerous others including renowned explorer Ralph Bagnold’s expedition in 1931, with further exploration from László Almásy and Leo Frobenius in 1933. The largest professional exploration of the massif to date was made in 1968 by a team of Belgian scientists.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
